subject: Gardening
title: Villa d'Este: Water as Art
description: A short lesson to help you apply Villa d'Este: Water as Art.

hook.text: Villa d'Este in Tivoli has 500 fountains, and not one of them uses a pump. Pure gravity powers everything.

buildup.text: Cardinal Ippolito d'Este built this Renaissance masterpiece in the 1560s on a steep hillside near Rome.

discovery.text: Engineers diverted an entire river through underground tunnels to feed the fountain system from above.

twist.text: The Fountain of the Organ once played music using water pressure to push air through organ pipes.

climax.text: Villa d'Este proved that water could be sculpted like marbleâ€”a liquid art form that still flows 460 years later.

punchline.text: Five hundred fountains, zero pumps, pure engineering.

quiz.question: How were Villa d'Este's 500 fountains powered?
options: Steam engines hidden in underground chambers
A diverted river feeding the system by gravity alone
Manual water pumps operated by garden workers
